title: Modeling a Periodic Context-Jump Rope, Part A

content.question: Part A The graph of <math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented. Determine possible coordinates <math alttext="open parentheses t comma h open parentheses t close parentheses close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></math> for the five points: <math alttext="F"><mi>F</mi></math>, <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math>, <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math>, <math alttext="K"><mi>K</mi></math>, and <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math>. 5 points are on the graph as follows: Point F is at the first peak. Point G is on the midline between the first peak and the first trough. Point J is at the first trough. Point K is on the midline between the first trough and the second peak. Point P is at the second peak.

topic.text: 3.7: Sinusoidal Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
